How many bags of trash have you gone through?
(This week or since your last check-in)
small bags (8 gal)

How many minutes did you spend in the shower today?
We tend to think we shower shorter than we do. Be honest with this amount of time.
How many baths did you take today?
How many loads of laundry did you do today?
How long did you spend hand-washing dishes today?
How many times did you run the dishwasher today?
How long did you spend washing your face today?
(With the water running)
How long did you have the water running while you brushed your teeth today?
Are there other times you used running water that haven\'t been accounted for? Add that time here.
(Washing hands, cleaning things, rinsing things, cooking, drinking…)
Do you have a water-conserving toilet?
It would be labeled WaterSense.
minutes

It\'ll be added to your total for this week. Look at your past usage to see if you\'re improving!
It\'ll be added to your total for today. Look at your past usage to see if you\'re improving!
Trash doesn\'t just disappear. It goes into landfills.
Home
Learn a Fact
Choose what to check in for
SHOWERS/BATHS
RESTROOM
LAUNDRY
DISH WASHING
PERSONAL CARE
The average person generates over 4 pounds of trash every day and about 1.5 tons of solid waste per year.
Environmental Protection Agency. "Municipal Solid Waste." EPA. Accessed March 28, 2014.

Americans make more than 200 million tons of garbage each year, enough to fill Busch Stadium from top to bottom twice a day. (Busch Stadium is home of the MLB St. Louis Cardinals. The stadium has a seating capacity of 43,975.)
Environmental Protection Agency. "10 FAST FACTS ON RECYCLING." EPA. http://www.epa.gov/reg3wcmd/solidwasterecyclingfacts.htm. Accessed July 13, 2014.
Over 75\%% of waste is recyclable, but we only recycle about 30\%% of it.
Green Waste. "A Brighter Shade of Green." Recycling Stats. Accessed March 28, 2014.
We generate 21.5 million tons of food waste each year. If we composted that food, it would reduce the same amount of greenhouse gas as taking 2 million cars off the road.
Green Waste. "A Brighter Shade of Green." Recycling Stats. Accessed March 28, 2014.
Recycling one aluminum can saves enough energy to listen to a full album on your iPod. Recycling 100 cans could light your bedroom for two whole weeks.
SustainAbility. "Recycling Facts." Sustainability-Recycling. Accessed March 28, 2014.
Recycling aluminum cans saves 95\%% of the energy used to make aluminum cans from new material.
Earth911, Inc.. "Facts About Aluminum Recycling." Earth911.com. Accessed March 28, 2014.
Americans throw away 25,000,000 plastic bottles every hour.
Green Waste. "A Brighter Shade of Green." Recycling Stats. Accessed March 28, 2014.
If every American recycled just one-tenth of their newspapers, we could save about 25 million trees each year.
SustainAbility. "Recycling Facts." Sustainability-Recycling. Accessed March 28, 2014.

We drink very little of our drinking water. Generally speaking, less than 1\%% of the treated water produced by water utilities is actually consumed. The rest goes on lawns, in washing machines, and down toilets and drains.
Department Of Water Supply. “55 Facts, Figures, and Follies of Water Conservation.” http://www.co.maui.hi.us/DocumentCenter/Home/View/4334.

If everyone in the United States could manage to use just one less gallon of water per shower every day, we could save some 85 billion gallons per year. How do you do it? By keeping the shower pressure lower or by making your showers a few seconds shorter.
Department Of Water Supply. “55 Facts, Figures, and Follies of Water Conservation.” http://www.co.maui.hi.us/DocumentCenter/Home/View/4334.

If you have a lawn, chances are it\'s your biggest water gobbler. Typically, at least 50\%% of water consumed by households is used outdoors. Inside your house, bathroom facilities claim nearly 75\%% of the water used.
Department Of Water Supply. “55 Facts, Figures, and Follies of Water Conservation.” http://www.co.maui.hi.us/DocumentCenter/Home/View/4334.

It takes a considerable amount of energy to deliver and treat the water you use every day. For example, letting your faucet run for five minutes uses about as much energy as letting a 60-watt light bulb run for 22 hours.
United States Environmental Protection Agency. "Why Water Efficiency." http://www.epa.gov/watersense/our_water/why_water_efficiency.html.

The WaterSense label will help you identify high-efficiency products, homes and programs. These water efficient options provide the same performance and quality you\'ve come to expect, but with the added benefit of water savings.
United States Environmental Protection Agency. "What You Can Do." http://www.epa.gov/watersense/our_water/what_you_can_do.html.
The average family spends $1,100 per year in water costs, but can save $350 from retrofitting with WaterSense labeled fixtures and ENERGY STAR® qualified appliances.
United States Environmental Protection Agency. "Why Water Efficiency." http://www.epa.gov/watersense/our_water/why_water_efficiency.html.
Heating water for bathing, shaving, cooking, and cleaning also requires a lot of energy. Homes with electric water heaters, for example, spend one-quarter of their electric bill just to heat water.
United States Environmental Protection Agency. "Why Water Efficiency." http://www.epa.gov/watersense/our_water/why_water_efficiency.html.
Average daily U.S. domestic water use (including outdoor) is 27.4 billion gallons.
American Water Works Association. "Water Use Statistics." http://www.drinktap.org/home/water-information/conservation/water-use-statistics.aspx.

string.name: why_waste_less_1
string.b:
Wasting less is for you if you…
 - want to help the environment
 - want to save money
 - want to help less-fortunate people in the world

resources.string:
We've all heard how our waste contributes to the environment being less healthy, and it makes sense that we can save money when we use less resources, especially gasoline and water. But there's a different reason why your decreased usage can impact many lives in the world - but it takes one more step. Once you've saved money by conserving your resources, you can make a real difference by donating that money to charities that help people meet their practical physical needs.


What if, instead of paying for and wasting clean drinking water, we used only what we need and helped others get access to clean water?


What if, instead of paying for food that we ultimately didn't end up eating (or let go bad), we bought only what we needed and gave the left over money to starving people on our streets or across the world?


"There is plenty on this earth to suit our needs, but there will never ever be enough to satisfy our greed."
 -Jenny and Tyler , "Love Through Me"


Let's not be greedy with the resources around us. These things take lifestyle changes and are not easy, but we can change lives from what would have been our overflow. You don't have to be rich by American standards to give to others.

 Turn your usage savings into money to make a real difference, starting now.
